ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: No other modes
Live virtual lecture that was recorded to also watch later
I also attended virtual office hours, which were scheduled and held virtually.

-in person lecture 
-office hours 
-slides and recorded videos

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: overview of all aspects of operating systems, focused on virtual memory, concurrency, and file systems
I learned about the operation of operating systems and how computers function at a low level. I got a lot of hands-on experience with OS

I learned about the individual parts that make up computers and how the operating system works from when it is first boot-loaded to standard computer usage. The course goes more in depth following systems programming, and there was maybe a quarter of repeat material, but I definitely gained a lot more confidence in all of it. Prof. Shao did a really good job of selling the importance of the course - my favorite applications of OS are its futures in smart devices like self-driving cars and even quantum computers.

At a high level OS gives you the tools to discuss and understand every layer of a typical computer. At a low level we learned to implement User / Kernel Abstraction, virtual memory / paging, syscalls/traps/interrupts, file systems, concurrency and synchronization.
How to design and program an operating system kernel almost from scratch
I learned the principles of operating systems. It's all very cool. We obviously didn't implement an OS from scratch, but rather implemented individual aspects that we learned about in lecture.
Core OS concepts and OS design.

I learned about the different factors that go into understanding operating systems (abstractions, layers, assembly code, etc.) I also gained a deeper appreciation for the careful consideration that goes into designing an operating system.
An overview of concepts in operating system design and systems engineering.
I learned a lot about Operating systems, particularly within synchronization, concurrent programming, and memory management
What design challenges operating systems have addressed and how these are implemented in modern OS.
Learned about different roles of the OS as well as its implementation.
We gained an in depth knowledge of the inner workings and roles of modern operating systems.

Serious insight into operating systems layer design, debugging techniques, and abstract user level system tools.

Also, finance job advice.
SO MUCH - I learned the basics of how operating systems work. 10/10 would recommend

-I learned how an operating system works! 
-Asynchronous behavior and parallel programming
-scheduling policies 
-the boot up process of a PC
-Assembly code 
-graphics mode 
-memory allocation 
-virtual paging
I learned all about Operating Systems and how to be a good programmer. A significant amount of time was also dedicated to multi-CPU concurrent programming.

A broad overview of OS abstractions, the kernel, memory management and access, storage (including file systems), devices (I/O and drivers), and multithreading/concurrency.  Brief introductions to security, networking, real-time systems.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: interesting lectures, though not particularly related to the assignments. 6 assignments that take ~20 hours each, though can be done with a partner. The assignments are occasionally a bit tedious to complete (namely, hw5, implementing a shell), but usually fairly rewarding.  Reasonably difficult exam, but take home due to  COIVD
It is a lot of work but you learn a lot in this class

Just like in systems programming, the programming assignments and the office hours are crucial to success. Our TAs were all very bright and supportive. Another strength of the class is encouraging students to form teams of 2 to do the programming assignments together. This is the first programming class I've taken at Yale that has had this, but I think it's a great model since it forces students to collaborate and explain their thought processes, which really sharpens programming skills, especially those applicable to industry.
Strength was the engagement of Prof. Shao and the quality of his teaching and his TAs. No weaknesses

Strengths: Professor Shao could explain OS concepts in incredible depth, but was also able to use analogies and explain their relevance to real-life situations. The labs were incredibly challenging but ensured that we all had to how each part of the OS functioned to complete them.
Weaknesses: Office hour zoom rooms should have been created by the TAs instead of the students, and the queue was often glitchy.
It was awesome. Took a lot away from the course and gave me a better understanding of how computers actually work.

I enjoyed the problem sets, although the lectures were often not needed to do the assignments and I found it difficult to refresh topics in lecture regularly until the midterm, which covered everything we had learned.

The lecture was great and the projects were very topical. I think working with the toy OS and implementing features we discussed in class was a great way to reinforce learning. One issue I had was the temporal disconnect between the project timeline and the lecture timeline. Sometimes it felt like too much time had passed between learning the content and applying it, and while spaced repetition can be helpful, I think it's best to get both of those pieces up front.

Strengths: Professor Shao is a pretty great lecturer. The problem sets are pretty cool.

Weaknesses: The pair programming setup probably causes someone to get carried in mosts pairs, which isn't great for learning.
The problem sets were crucial to grasping the material for ourselves. They were very well organized and managed. I only wish that there could be larger projects with more collaboration.

Strengths: Phenomenal lecturer. Amazing psets. 
Weaknesses: Offive hour structure.

Strengths: good lectures, enthusiastic and helpful professors (and TAs), well-written and well-designed psets

Weaknesses: none that I can think of

Amazing prof, wonderful job at explaining concepts. He sometimes goes fast in lectures but he stops often and asks if anyone has questions (it can still feel intimidating to ask). He also stays after class in case you didnt want to ask during recorded lecture! Absolutely amazing and very kind and considerate. He is also very funny and his metaphors are quite creative.
Prof Shao really knows what he's talking about and is very fun. The assignments are excellent and well-organized, and it is nice to be able to pair program them with a friend.
The material is very interesting, and the course manages to cover quite a lot, but the lectures are largely disconnected for the problem sets, especially towards the end of the course.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The lectures were well presented and as good as they could have been
Recorded lectures, virtual office hours were good
The methods of collaborating with your Lab partner were often pretty flawed and required a lot of effort. But then again, I'm not sure what a better way to virtually colab on a coding pset would be.
I think lecture was definitely good, but that the office hours were much better adapted since they were held one-on-one over Zoom, and were tremendously helpful.
Slides and recordings were great. Office hours were good as well.
The virtual lectures were fine. I felt like it was essential to meet together to discuss concepts when implementing the problem sets, though.

Success: Lecture and midterm
Improve: Office hours
I think there could have been more questions / interactions initiated by students but that was mostly the students' fault. It was also late in the day which probably didn't help after a day of Zoom.

Having asynchronous modes of contact was especially helpful this semester -- Zhong Shao and all the TAs were all very helpful and easy to communicate with, and the Piazza board definitely was a huge asset as well. From what I could tell, Prof. Shao didn't really change the way that he taught the class in terms of lectures, which still worked well because, well, he's a great professor. I think encouraging people to participate through questions and perhaps having more of a cameras on time might help with engagement. And despite physical distance, keeping the pair programming aspect of the homework was definitely a large part that kept me engaged throughout the semester.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes

The course was interesting but the newness of the content highly depends on whether you had Prof. Bhattacharjee or Prof. Eisenstat for CS 323. I took 323 with Prof. Bhattacharjee, while my project partner took it with Prof. Eisenstat, and for me about 50-60% of the content was review, while for my partner nearly everything was new. If you took 323 with Prof. Bhattacharjee, taking this course might still be valuable to reinforce concepts from 323 and dig deeper into them, but expect it to be on the easier side for you.
You will do a lot of work but it is worth it. The class is extremely well organized.
Yes. In the words of another CS alum, Once youve taken OS, theyll never be a technical problem you cant face
If you are interested in games and/or AI, this class will be down your alley. As a person sorta interested in AI but not really games, it wasn't as interested, but learned a lot

Yes, I'd definitely recommend it, both for the theoretical aspect and for the actual coding. It's a very good continuation of 323. Just make sure to find a partner for the labs. If you don't you will most likely have a very rough go at this class.
Absolutely.
If you're a CS major, you have to know about OS. Lots of important concepts to know about how computers work under-the-hood and how to implement them.

Yes, for any computer science student. It was rewarding to understand the intricacies of operating systems and build upon a lot of knowledge from CS323. It is also great to familiarize oneself with assembly code and to practice it extensively in problem sets in this class.

Yes. While some topics overlap with 323, the extension into OS specifics makes this class almost must-take for anyone looking to understand computer science or how computers work in general. Class is well taught and professor Shao is a great lecturer!
Yes, if you're a CS major. Even though this stuff is pretty low-level, it seems like stuff that is important for all programmers to understand, at least to some degree.
Of course, for any CS major.
Absolutely. This course should be mandatory for a BS in computer science. It's such a phenomenal course and will improve every student that takes it.
YES! If you have the time in your schedule and you're a CS major (or interested in CS and have taken 323), take this course!

Absolutely. One of the best classes I have taken at Yale. An amazing CS elective and it teaches you a lot about all computer systems. I would recommend this class to everyone to have a better understanding of how a computer actually works (scheduling, preemption, interrupts, exceptions, etc) to create the appearance of a dedicated machine for programs.

For sure. Operating Systems are a fundamental and fascinating part of Computer Science. You write a working operating system over the duration of the semester which is really satisfying, and even if you don't work on an operating system again the skills learned will make you a much better programmer overall. Professor Shao is great, and he makes sure to emphasize how topics discussed in class apply to life outside of computers (which is kind of fun).

If you were looking for a class to take after 323 (although maybe not RIGHT after) that integrates the class content and homework a little more, AND you're looking to do a fair amount of programming (lower-level, with another person), I would recommend this class. Zhong Shao's lectures are very well organized, the course is structured well to give students the support they need even amidst their struggling, and the content is pretty interesting. Even if you don't plan on going super low-level, any computer that we use is bound to have an OS and it's nice to know a little of what's going on under the hood.
Yes.  I think this course provides a great deal more detail in systems programming than 323, and does so with practical assignments.
